Market manipulation is indeed a concern

and uh again two out of three Farmers

we're looking indeed at um collaboration
so just very briefly the way that we
really got started in the Farm Bureau
with this it was about 4 years ago um uh
Farmers started calling us uh right
after planting and saying hey you know
such and such a company came out and
they visited me and they wanted me to
put this little G Gizmo on my tractor
and then give them the data for what
came out um during planting and later on
and harvesting and I either did or I
didn't sign the contract that they gave
me but now that planting is over I read
the contract and I'm not very happy
about what it says what do you know
about it and we said had to say we don't
know anything about it so um as Farm
Bureau we went around and met with seven
or eight companies and tried to figure
out you know what are you putting in
your privacy documents what are you
putting in your terms and condition you
know is it really the right thing for
the farmers Etc um and when we finished

some work to do um and surprisingly just
five or six months later there had been
enough discussion about it in the
country that uh we had a significant
amount of policy put into our policy
book we have a policy book that
is something about everything that
affects every Farmer's pocketbook in
this country I mean it might be
immigration laws for specialty crop
producers or it might be uh estate taxes
or whatever but all of a sudden we had
this big data privacy policy that we had
never had before and a couple months
later the Farmers Union and the corn
producers and the soybean folks had
exactly whoops the same um kinds of
policies as we did and so we decided
let's call folks together and just sit
down and chat so we put together low
Coalition of these seven a groups and
the six a tech providers that are up
there and we said we just want to talk
about privacy policy and terms and
conditions and transferability and
portability and all those things and we
spent about seven or eight months and
indeed we came up with um kind of one
little paragraphs on um all of these
things what do we think about
transparency about portability about
terms about disclosure etc etc and this
was something this wasn't this is what
agriculture thinks this is what all 13
of the groups think and we went back and
forth a whole lot and then after that
point in time we opened it up to other
groups that couldn't be part of that 13
because we just were you know Limited in
room as far as having the ability to
really have good one-on-one discussions
and we said hey if you believe in these
things we'd love to have you join so we
now have 38 groups that have signed
those uh principles but again it was all
collaboration
um one of the things we found through
those discussions and we we all said
great we got these principles but you
know having them on a piece of paper is
one thing and actually having them sort
of mean something with something else
and so um at Farm buau we embarked on a
couple of projects and the first was um
a transparency EV evaluator and it came
about because we had lots of farmers
that said my gosh these privacy policies
and these terms and conditions documents
are really long and really complex and
I'm not a lawyer and I really don't want
to hire a lawyer to look at this stuff
but I'm you know hesitant about signing
it and so we decided that it might be
important to see if there was a way to
um a drive companies to write better
more transparent policies and B make it
easier for Farmers to indeed figure out
what was in those policies and so again
we um put out a call and said hey who
would be interested in participating in
this and we had uh I think it's eight
farmer organizations there and 17 um
agtech providers as you can see it's a
very um uh it's a very broad group it's
all kinds of companies it's all kinds of
agricultural
organizations um but again it wasn't
talking about what do we want to do to
pass a law it was talking about
collaboration and how can we really make
this work and so what we came up with
was what we call an a data transparency
evaluator and the simplest way I know to
explain it is it's kind of a a
combination of a consumer reports and a
Good Housekeeping seal of approval and
so um uh we came up with indeed 10
questions and this is like the whole
form right there in front of you a
fairly simple process where a company
says yep I'm willing to submit my
policies to this transparency evaluator
so if I look for example at um I think
it's number nine there it says or number
eight upon my request can my original
data set be deleted when my contract
terminates um the second thing is yes or
no it's not no it can't or yes it can
it's just is it transparent in the
policy or in the contract so people can
understand it and then the third column
would be actually a hyperlink to the
actual place in the policy so I don't
have to read through 20 pages to figure
out what does it say about X um and then
indeed if the company uh answers those
qu 10 questions correctly they get that
little seal that says a data transparent
and you can see conservice there has
used it on the front of their privacy
policy it's yours to use for a year and
whatever marketing tools you want to
make um I happen to hear the president
of uh conservice speak a couple of
months ago and he said it's been one of

member relations with our folks that um

here trying to make sure that we're
indeed following through um now again
I'm going to point this out this is a

not yet um
uh put their policy through the Privacy
uh uh through the transparency evaluator
but you can see in the second um
